head.title: A War Over Rent, on Two Coasts

hedline.hl1: A War Over Rent, on Two Coasts

abstract.p: Richard Smith letter says Paul Krugman's argument for a free market in housing (June 7 Op-Ed column) is wrong because land, unlike other commodities, is inelastic

Paul Krugman is correct that nearly all American economists agree that rent control is a bad thing (column, June 7). But Mr. Krugman is as wrong as the textbooks if he thinks that rental housing, like any other commodity, should be entirely left to the free market because market forces will bring supply into line with demand.

This universally preached free-market theory is nonsense because, unlike most ordinary commodities like groceries or cars, land is inelastic. Land in these heavily populated cities cannot be ''produced'' in response to rising demand. Because the landlords collectively possess an effective extra market monopoly of this unique ''commodity,'' demand can drive up the cost of rent infinitely. Is it any wonder that tenants in San Francisco or New York have responded to the landlords' collective monopoly by seeking to bring in extra market government regulation (rent control) to offset the extra market power of the landlords?
